dt: {bc}conjuration {dx_def}see {dxt|conjure||2a}{/dx_def} of the spirits of the dead for purposes of magically revealing the future or influencing the course of events

dt.t: The novel centers on the practice of {wi}necromancy{/wi} and its influence on the world of the living.

et: Middle English {it}nycromancie{/it} "sorcery, conjuration of spirits," borrowed from Late Latin {it}necromantīa{/it} "divination from an exhumed corpse," borrowed from Late Greek {it}nekromanteía{/it} "divination by conjuration of the dead," from Greek {it}nekro-{/it} {et_link|necro-|necr-} + {it}-manteia{/it} {et_link|-mancy|-mancy}; replacing earlier Middle English {it}nigromance, nygromancye,{/it} borrowed from Anglo-French {it}nigromance, nigromancie,{/it} borrowed from Medieval Latin {it}nigromantia,{/it} alteration of {it}necromantia{/it} by association with Latin {it}nigr-, niger{/it} "black"

The ancient Greek correspondents to later {it}nekromanteía{/it} were {it}nekyomanteía{/it} and {it}nékyia{/it} (from {it}nékȳs{/it} "corpse"), the former used particularly to describe Odysseus's journey to Hades in Book 11 of the {it}Odyssey{/it} to consult the spirits of the dead.
shortdef: conjuration of the spirits of the dead for purposes of magically revealing the future or influencing the course of events
